overview.short: Borrelia species are Gram-negativeâ€“like, microaerophilic spirochetes transmitted primarily by arthropod vectors.
overview.clinical_context: Includes agents of Lyme disease and relapsing fever, characterised by systemic dissemination and immune evasion.

field_notes.Gram Stain: Poorly visualised with Gram stain; silver stains or dark-field microscopy are preferred.
field_notes.Media Grown On: Requires specialised enriched media; not recoverable on routine laboratory agar.
field_notes.Motility: Characteristic corkscrew motility due to periplasmic flagella.

key_differentiators.notes: Spirochetal morphology with loose coils differentiates Borrelia from other spirochetes.
Borrelia cannot be cultured on routine bacteriological media.
Endoflagella-driven motility is characteristic of spirochetes.

common_confusions.reason: Shared spirochete morphology and poor Gram stain visibility.
Overlapping spiral morphology but differing clinical syndromes and motility patterns.

when_to_question_identification: Isolate grows readily on routine agar.
Strong carbohydrate fermentation reactions are reported.
Lack of spirochete morphology on dark-field or silver stain.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Primary diagnostic method due to fastidious growth.
Standard approach for Lyme disease diagnosis.
Direct visualisation of spirochetes in clinical specimens.
